titleInfo.title: Reward Sensitivity and Its Relationship to Initiation of Alcohol Use and Past Month Consumption in Female Adolescents

mods:mods.abstract: Adolescence is a period of increased risk-taking behaviors including the initiation of alcohol use, which appears mechanistically related to the brain's reward system. Available evidence provides support for both hyposensitivity and hypersensitivity as mediators of substance or alcohol use escalation – calling for further research to better understand the role of reward systems in risk trajectories, utilizing effective indices of reward processing. The reward positivity (RewP) is a commonly utilized index of hedonic "liking," an important aspect of reward activation. Existing studies with adults have provided evidence for reduced, enhanced, or intact RewP among samples with risk for, or histories of problem drinking or other harmful substance use. However, to date, no research has examined relations between youth alcohol use and RewP, although research on adolescents at risk for substance use, or currently using tobacco or cannabis, has not found differences in RewP relative to adolescent controls, outside of one past sex-specific finding in adolescent males. The current study measured the RewP within a binary-choice reward task in a large sample (N = 250) of adolescent females (Mage = 14.40) to evaluate its predictive association with self-reported drinking initiation and past-month drinking. Regression analyses showed that adolescents who had initiated drinking exhibited a smaller RewP—specifically, a smaller response to monetary gain feedback—compared to not-yet drinkers. There was no difference in RewP between past-month drinkers and non-drinkers. These findings provide evidence for the importance of limited capacity for hedonic "liking" as a risk factor for early initiation of drinking in adolescent females, while other patterns may underlie likelihood for proximal drinking escalation. Future studies should incorporate additional indices of reward activation, and mixed-sex samples with greater drinking variability to replicate current study findings and test for sex moderation of observed reward-response/drinking associations.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Greg Hajcak, Professor Directing Thesis; Christopher J. Patrick, Committee Member; James Kevin McNulty, Committee Member.
